A field is a commutative division ring.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Does the concept of a/an Field need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand the concept of a Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension, it is essential to first comprehend what a field is, as the definition of the Galois group directly involves fields. The definition of the Galois group mentions it as the group of field automorphisms of $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ that fix $\mathbb{F}_q$, where both $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ and $\mathbb{F}_q$ are fields. The concept of a field is fundamental here because without knowing what a field is, one cannot understand the nature of the objects ($\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ and $\mathbb{F}_q$) being discussed or the operations (automorphisms) that are permissible on them. Moreover, the properties of fields, such as being a commutative division ring, are crucial to defining what kinds of transformations (automorphisms) can exist and how they behave. Therefore, the concept of a field is necessary to define and understand the Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension.
